Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Predicting Healthcare Fraud, Waste and Abuse by Automatically Discovering Social Networks in Health Insurance Claims Data through Machine Learning
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will pave the way for new types of social network analysis to detect anomalies, which could lead to more accurate and faster identification of Fraud, Waste, and Abuse (FWA), key opinion leaders (i.e., influentials), and market segments. Medicare and other healthcare providers lose hundreds of millions of dollars to FWA. This research proposes using a novel way to discover and combine relationships between entities (e.g., doctors) with information about the entities (e.g., prescription history) using machine learning. The goal is to reduce a claims investigator's workload while maintaining high accuracy in detecting FWA. In short, the results of this research will not only improve FWA detection efficiency, but enable detecting new types of FWA. Societal impact includes reduced costs to the taxpayer for government supported programs such as Medicare through better FWA detection. More broadly, the system could be used to find terrorist and crime networks, detect possible opioid or substance abuse epidemic cohorts, under-medication, over-medication, and even incorrect medications.

The proposed project will apply a novel machine learning method to solve the Fraud, Waste, and Abuse (FWA) problem in health insurance. The technical problem is how to combine relations between entities such as doctors with information about doctors (e.g., a doctor's prescription history). This project advances the state of the art by developing a new way to automatically discover those relations and then combining those relations with the information about doctors through machine learning, thus vastly improving prediction accuracy. The method uses relation information to fill in the gaps of entity information alone and vice versa. It is believed that this method will hugely improve the ability to detect FWA. The goal is to achieve a 50% true positive rate in a database of fraud-convicted doctors published monthly by the government. The scope of the project involves analyzing several different types of health insurance claims formats (e.g., Medicare) and producing a fraud score, which then others can use. The anticipated results include a fraud score for most doctors in the U.S. (at least those who deal with Medicare), APIs to these scores, and an interactive visual system that claims investigators can use to reduce their workload while accurately identifying FWA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cover

Project Outcome Report (POR) 

Federal Grant or Other Identifying Number Assigned by Agency:

1648542

Project Title:

SBIR Phase I: Predicting Healthcare Fraud, Waste and Abuse by Automatically Discovering Social Networks in Health Insurance Claims Data through Machine Learning

PD/PI Name:

  • Armand E Prieditis, Principal Investigator

Recipient Organization:

Albeado, Inc

Project/Grant Period:

12/01/2016 - 11/30/2017

Reporting Period:

12/01/2016 - 11/30/2017

Submitting Official (if other than PD\PI):

  • Armand E Prieditis
  • Principal Investigator

Submission Date:

02/28/2018

Signature of Submitting Official (signature shall be submitted in accordance with agency specific instructions)

Armand E Prieditis

Subtopic: SH3

 

Keywords: fraud, waste, and abuse prediction, anomaly detection, unsupervised learning, clustering,

claims investigation.

 

Overview:

 

Fraud, Waste, and Abuse (FWA) is an enormous problem within the US healthcare system. Statistics shows 10 cents of every dollar spent on healthcare is in fraudulent or unneeded service claims. The technical challenge is that finding FWA in a mountain of data, automatically and accurately, is extremely difficult.

 

Currently, that challenge is overwhelming the capabilities of the health care sector payers like private insurance companies or Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and law enforcement agencies like FBI and Office of Inspector General (OIG), Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). Existing processes for claims adjudication is a mix of pre-defined software filtering systems and human intensive detective work scrutinizing the flagged claims. As a result, only a small fraction of claims involving FWA are caught before payments are made.

 

The objective of the project of building an anomaly detection technology based on unsupervised machine learning system that can learn to predict FWA based on historical health-insurance claims data, even when examples of FWA are few and far between, was achieved. Although high in Dollar value, the frequency of FWA is very small (more than 95% of claims by volume are clean), making the True Positive Prediction Rate of FWA really difficult. The completed project not only demonstrates improvement in the efficiency with which FWA is detected but resulted in the detection of new types of FWA that would be impossible or difficult to detect without the results of this project.

 

The validation of correctly detecting FWA came from comparing our predictions to a list of prosecuted health insurance fraud and abuse cases published at the HHS OIG website.

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project applied a novel machine learning method to solve the Fraud, Waste, and Abuse (FWA) problem in health care industry. It advances the state of the art by augmenting the claims data with features using unsupervised machine learning and graph theoretic methods. The result combines information that characterizes relations between the entities in a network with information that characterizes the entities.  By incorporating network properties as additional features in global learning models, the project significantly boosted prediction accuracy, hugely improving our ability to detect FWA.

Broader Impacts:

 The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will usher new Machine Learning products delivering high accuracy. Scientifically, this project can pave the way for new types of network analysis that were not possible before.

Specifically, we expect the outcome of this project will lead to more accurate analysis of anomalous interactions (e.g., doctors and patients, or doctors and drugs), ultimately lowering the cost for healthcare delivery as well as reducing the exposure and reserve. Without extending resources and spending, law enforcement agencies can now investigate larger number of potential FWA cases and detect new and previously undetectable FWA tactics.  

PRISM displays the following network of suspected (orange) and normal physicians (green) and relationship (lines). This display uses a standard spring-based layout that tries to minimize the energy of  “springs” between each physician: the more relations between two physicians, the stiffer the spring. 

The user can also select Highlight Key Opinion Leaders to show which physicians are most influential, where influence is defined as described above. Key Opinion Leaders are important marketing asset.

Finally, the user can also select 2 Emergent Segments Found to show the two segments of physicians our system found automatically based on both attributes of physicians and relationships between physicians. The segments are shown as blue and red below. The triangles represent suspect physicians and the circles normal ones. This “market segmentation” is a side-effect of the clustering we described above.

From the Flagged Prescribers screen, the user can also select specific physicans and drill-down into their relations and information as shown.

 

Impacts

What is the impact on the development of the principal discipline(s) of the project?

The application of INML, the patent-pending method we developed which combines attributes and relationships, results in superior performance for detecting fraud, abuse and waste in healthcare. 

What is the impact on other disciplines?

The Integrated Network based Machine Learning (INML) method can be used to detect anomalies, more generally.
